0,Industrial_Gas_Turbines_AMY_Razak.txt,200,c8a5758a051ccc61e039d049715eb52832f885e249bcfacac165bb2e66655573,"Reductions in CO2 can be achieved only by improving energy efficiency or burning fuels of low carbon content. Figure 11.19 also represents CO2 emissions on an index basis, which is defined as the mass of CO2 emissions per kW h of power produced. The increase in thermal efficiency at lower ambient temperatures reduces the fuel flow per unit of power generated. Thus, the CO2 emission index decreases with decrease in ambient temperature.
Reduction in emissions of NOₓ, CO and UHCs have been achieved by the development of combustion technologies such as DLE combustors, where the emissions of NOx and CO are below 25 ppm.
11.20 Variation of NOₓ and CO with ambient temperature.
# 11.4 Effect of reduced power output during a change in ambient temperature

Preceding sections discussed the impact of ambient temperature on engine performance when the engine was operating on limits such as the exhaust gas temperature, gas generator speed and compressor non-dimensional speed. The case is now considered where the engine is operating at a low enough power output, such that no engine limit is reached during the same ambient temperature transient. To achieve this, the simulator is operated at an electrical power demand of 17.5 MW. As the ambient temperature decreases when operating at a constant power output (17.5 MW), the non-dimensional power (Power/P₁√T₁) will increase. Figure 11.7 shows that the non-dimensional power increases with the increase in compressor non-dimensional speed. Thus an increase in non-dimensional power implies an increase in compressor non-dimensional speed. This increase in non-dimensional speed will therefore result in an increase in compressor pressure ratio and temperature ratio, and other non-dimensional parameters, as shown in Figs 11.3 to 11.7.
# 11.4.1 Compressor characteristic

The operating point on the compressor characteristic during the ambient temperature transient is shown in Fig. 11.21. Due to the increase in compressor non-dimensional flow and pressure ratio, the operating point moves up the characteristic closely following the engine running line. Note that the movement of the operating point on the compressor characteristics is not as great as in the previous case when the engine was forced to operate on control system limits, as shown in Fig. 11.9.

column3: Operating point at end of the simulation (ambient temperature –30 degrees Celsius)

column2: Operating point at start of the simulation (ambient temperature 30 degrees Celsius)

column1: 11.21 Operating points on the compressor characteristic during ambient temperature transient and low-power operation.
# 11.4.2 Trends in speed

The trends of the gas generator and compressor non-dimensional speed are shown in Fig. 11.22. Observe that the compressor non-dimensional speed increases, as explained in Section 11.4. The gas generator speed, however, decreases with the decrease in ambient temperature. Note that the increase in compressor non-dimensional speed is not as great as was observed when the engine power output was constrained by a control system limit. Thus, the increase in compressor non-dimensional speed is smaller for a given fall in ambient temperature. The interaction of the component characteristics (compressor and turbines) and the shape of the compressor characteristic (including VIGV position) result in a continuous fall in the gas generator speed with decreasing ambient temperature.

Requires a drop in N₁/√T₁ increases as T₁ falls, but N₁ to maintain the required N₁/√T₁ as dictated by component matching between the compressor and turbines (speed compatibility). Thus this trend differs from the previous case where the gas generator speed was observed to increase as the ambient temperature decreased during constant EGT operation, as shown in Fig. 11.8.
# 11.4.3 Trends in pressure ratio

Figure 11.23 shows the trends in the pressure ratios of the engine components (compressor and turbines). The compressor pressure ratio is observed to increase due to the increase in compressor non-dimensional speed. The trend in the pressure ratio of the gas generator turbine is essentially constant.
11.22 Trends in speed during ambient temperature transient and low-power operation.
# Simulating the effects of ambient temperature on performance

column2: Maximum to minimum cycle temperature ratio

column1: 0 500 1000 1500 2000 2500 3000 3500 4000 Maximum to minimum cycle temperature ratio, gas
Time (seconds)
11.23 Trends in pressure ratio during ambient temperature transient and low-power operation.

is due to the choked conditions that prevail in the power turbine. Hence an increase in the power turbine pressure ratio is observed. The figure shows that the ratio of the maximum to minimum cycle temperature, T₃/T₁ also increases as the ambient temperature decreases.
# 11.4.4 Trends in power and thermal efficiency

As no engine limits are exceeded, the engine is capable of delivering the required power demand by the generator (17.5 MW) during the ambient temperature transient. The gas power also remains essentially constant, although a very slight decrease in gas power is observed, as seen in Fig. ",How can reductions in CO2 emissions be achieved according to the text?,Reductions in CO2 can be achieved by improving energy efficiency or burning fuels of low carbon content.,The text states that CO2 emissions can be reduced through enhanced energy efficiency or the use of low-carbon fuels.,"By either increasing energy efficiency or utilizing fuels with less carbon, CO2 emissions can be decreased.",Achieving lower CO2 emissions is possible via two methods: boosting energy efficiency or opting for fuels that have a low carbon content.,The passage mentions two strategies for CO2 reduction: improving how efficiently energy is used and choosing fuels that are low in carbon.

The gas power also remains essentially constant, although a very slight decrease in gas power is observed, as seen in Fig. ",What is the CO2 emission index and how does it relate to ambient temperature?,"The CO2 emission index is defined as the mass of CO2 emissions per kW h of power produced, and it decreases with a decrease in ambient temperature.","Defined as CO2 mass per kW h, the emission index falls as ambient temperatures drop, due to increased thermal efficiency.","A lower ambient temperature leads to a higher thermal efficiency, which in turn reduces the CO2 emission index, the mass of CO2 per kW h.","The CO2 emission index, measuring CO2 per kW h, diminishes with ambient temperature because thermal efficiency improves.","With ambient temperature decreasing, thermal efficiency rises, causing the CO2 emission index (CO2 mass per kW h) to decline."

Figure 11.19 also represents CO2 emissions on an index basis, which is defined as the mass of CO2 emissions per kW h of power produced. The increase in thermal efficiency at lower ambient temperatures reduces the fuel flow per unit of power generated. Thus, the CO2 emission index decreases with decrease in ambient temperature.
Reduction in emissions of NOₓ, CO and UHCs have been achieved by the development of combustion technologies such as DLE combustors, where the emissions of NOx and CO are below 25 ppm.
11.20 Variation of NOₓ and CO with ambient temperature.
# 11.4 Effect of reduced power output during a change in ambient temperature

Preceding sections discussed the impact of ambient temperature on engine performance when the engine was operating on limits such as the exhaust gas temperature, gas generator speed and compressor non-dimensional speed. The case is now considered where the engine is operating at a low enough power output, such that no engine limit is reached during the same ambient temperature transient. To achieve this, the simulator is operated at an electrical power demand of 17.5 MW. As the ambient temperature decreases when operating at a constant power output (17.5 MW), the non-dimensional power (Power/P₁√T₁) will increase. Figure 11.7 shows that the non-dimensional power increases with the increase in compressor non-dimensional speed. Thus an increase in non-dimensional power implies an increase in compressor non-dimensional speed. This increase in non-dimensional speed will therefore result in an increase in compressor pressure ratio and temperature ratio, and other non-dimensional parameters, as shown in Figs 11.3 to 11.7.
# 11.4.1 Compressor characteristic

The operating point on the compressor characteristic during the ambient temperature transient is shown in Fig. 11.21. Due to the increase in compressor non-dimensional flow and pressure ratio, the operating point moves up the characteristic closely following the engine running line. Note that the movement of the operating point on the compressor characteristics is not as great as in the previous case when the engine was forced to operate on control system limits, as shown in Fig. 11.9.

column3: Operating point at end of the simulation (ambient temperature –30 degrees Celsius)

column2: Operating point at start of the simulation (ambient temperature 30 degrees Celsius)

column1: 11.21 Operating points on the compressor characteristic during ambient temperature transient and low-power operation.
# 11.4.2 Trends in speed

The trends of the gas generator and compressor non-dimensional speed are shown in Fig. 11.22. Observe that the compressor non-dimensional speed increases, as explained in Section 11.4. The gas generator speed, however, decreases with the decrease in ambient temperature. Note that the increase in compressor non-dimensional speed is not as great as was observed when the engine power output was constrained by a control system limit. Thus, the increase in compressor non-dimensional speed is smaller for a given fall in ambient temperature. The interaction of the component characteristics (compressor and turbines) and the shape of the compressor characteristic (including VIGV position) result in a continuous fall in the gas generator speed with decreasing ambient temperature.

Requires a drop in N₁/√T₁ increases as T₁ falls, but N₁ to maintain the required N₁/√T₁ as dictated by component matching between the compressor and turbines (speed compatibility). Thus this trend differs from the previous case where the gas generator speed was observed to increase as the ambient temperature decreased during constant EGT operation, as shown in Fig. 11.8.
# 11.4.3 Trends in pressure ratio

Figure 11.23 shows the trends in the pressure ratios of the engine components (compressor and turbines). The compressor pressure ratio is observed to increase due to the increase in compressor non-dimensional speed. The trend in the pressure ratio of the gas generator turbine is essentially constant.
11.22 Trends in speed during ambient temperature transient and low-power operation.

11.23 Trends in pressure ratio during ambient temperature transient and low-power operation.

is due to the choked conditions that prevail in the power turbine. Hence an increase in the power turbine pressure ratio is observed. The figure shows that the ratio of the maximum to minimum cycle temperature, T₃/T₁ also increases as the ambient temperature decreases.
# 11.4.4 Trends in power and thermal efficiency

As no engine limits are exceeded, the engine is capable of delivering the required power demand by the generator (17.5 MW) during the ambient temperature transient. The gas power also remains essentially constant, although a very slight decrease in gas power is observed, as seen in Fig. ",What are the trends in pressure ratios of engine components during an ambient temperature transient at low-power operation?,"The compressor pressure ratio increases due to higher non-dimensional speed, while the gas generator turbine pressure ratio remains essentially constant.","During a temperature transient at low power, the compressor's pressure ratio rises with non-dimensional speed, but the gas generator turbine's pressure ratio stays nearly the same.","At low power, as ambient temperature decreases, the compressor pressure ratio goes up because of increased non-dimensional speed, whereas the gas generator turbine pressure ratio hardly changes.","The passage notes that, under low-power operation and decreasing ambient temperatures, the compressor pressure ratio increases with non-dimensional speed, but the gas generator turbine pressure ratio remains stable.","Under conditions of low power and falling ambient temperatures, the compressor pressure ratio increases in response to higher non-dimensional speed, while the gas generator turbine pressure ratio maintains a constant trend."

The gas power also remains essentially constant, although a very slight decrease in gas power is observed, as seen in Fig. ",What is the effect of ambient temperature on engine power and thermal efficiency during low-power operation?,"During low-power operation, the engine can meet the power demand (17.5 MW) across ambient temperature changes, with gas power remaining nearly constant and a slight decrease observed.","At low power, the engine maintains the required 17.5 MW output despite ambient temperature variations, with gas power staying mostly steady, though slightly decreasing.","The text mentions that, during low-power operation, the engine delivers consistent power (17.5 MW) as ambient temperature changes, with gas power almost unchanged but showing a minor decline.","Under low-power conditions, ambient temperature transients do not prevent the engine from achieving the 17.5 MW demand, with gas power largely constant but experiencing a slight reduction.","During operation at low power, the engine sustains the 17.5 MW power output through ambient temperature shifts, with gas power remaining essentially stable, albeit with a small decrease."
